Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I can now use MatLab confidently and I understand how programming is used to model biological systems and processes.
Learned a lot of statistics and MATLAB coding.

This is a great class the fosters the thinking needed for problem-solving. The course also provides insight into what biomedical engineering is and a great course for scientists and engineers interested in learning how to code.

I gained a deep understanding of the basics of Matlab coding, computer logic, thinking in terms of code and math, statistical analysis of stochastic data, and more. This class was in depth and was effective in teaching several skills that I anticipate will be very useful in future courses and jobs.
You learn the basics of MATLAB and how to use MATLAB in biomedical engineering modeling scenarios.
I learnt a bit about Matlab and how to use it to analyze data.
Learned how to use Matlab but it was a little fast paced for someone with zero coding experience
I learned basic coding and using simple concepts to model cell interactions.
I learned how to model biological systems using matlab. I also was exposed to statistics relevant to experiments.
I learned a basic overview of matlab.
MatLab programming, basic modeling
I learned how to use MATLAB and also some basic statistical analysis strategies.
I think a strength was the content of the course because it was very interesting. However, the lectures were very dry and definitely should have been more engaging.

Pretty poorly taught. Not engaging as we only sat in class and stared at code that Prof Mak typed up at a million miles an hour. Material is interesting, though. Cool psets but you better be on top of your coding/logic skills.
Very well organized.

The course content was definitely strong, and we got a lot of good advice and help from the TAs. I would say, however, that the teaching could have been far more effective with a bit more of a personable and accessible attitude as well as some changes to teaching style that started to happen near the end of the semester. For example, for most of the course, we essentially watched the professor code long functions that were often very repetitive, so that there were minimal explanations of new concepts, yet we still wasted time on repeating certain simplistic sections of code. To fix this, I would simply give the students code in advance, and spend class time explaining the logic behind each line of code. In addition, a slightly more personable attitude would have helped make the class a little more engaging for students during lecture, rather than only when doing problem sets.
The course was not too fast passed and did a good job of focusing on the basics before building into more complicated examples.

The class is generally poorly taught. Professor Mak is definitely extremely smart but is quite terrible at teaching. He types codes so fast, and we can't keep up with him. He does not give a lot of background on the significance of the codes and assumes a lot of our abilities when most students ideally come into the class with no background in coding. I think this class should be taught very differently. The codes should be posted before lecture, and Prof Mak should comment in his code so we don't get lost trying to understand it. We evaluated the course before the spring break but there was no significant change after. TA sections should be after Wednesday when the psets are posted so we can get the chance to ask questions.
It is a good intro to matlab but I think people should take stats before taking this course? Also a lot of matlab functions went unexplained
The course tried to teach several different topics at once and was not very cohesive.
The course is clear about what it expects you to be able to do, but lectures could be made more engaging to facilitate direct application of these skills.

Weaknesses: the math component of the course is sometimes assumed to be known, or explained in a white board. I wish that the math component and the meaaning of some codes were explained more in class, like the why to use a certain code or loop.
I think the course tried to squeeze too much in so ended up feeling rushed.
The professor of this course was not good. He was not engaging with the class, was very monotone, and didn't show much effort into our work.

lectures are quite boring, could be more interactive. 
I also think final project could be used to replace the final exam, because, after all when you need to program for research or other purposes, it's not how fast you can make the program, but how close the simulation is to real life, or how clever the design is. 

I feel like the final exam is just regurgitation of things that Prof Mak talked about in class.

Strengths: presents a decent overview of the MATLAB skills that are necessary for a biomedical engineering major.   Codes are posted online, which helps if yours wasn't working in class for an unknown reason.  

Weaknesses:  the class material is presented in the most boring way imaginable.  Also, questions asked in class are frequently not answered well.
Yes! It is definitely very interesting and challenging. Exactly what a Yale course should be.
If you want to learn matlab, take it. If you are BME, you need to take it. Otherwise, don't take it. Don't expect to have a good time, but expect to become rather proficient in basic simulations.
Great course. Very enjoyable.

I would take this course if you are a prospective Biomedical Engineering major who needs the requirement and has an interest in using Matlab for computation and simulations. It would not be a great course for someone who was not already interested in the subject.
Only take this course is you are majoring in biomedical engineering.
Nope, I ideally would not recommend this class, unless you absolutely have to take it.
Its for the major so take it I guess
I would if you're a bme student because it's for the most part manageable.

No, I would not recommend this course unless it was a requirement for your major. It is not well taught, the professor is not very good at engaging the students and expects you to know how to do everything even when the students had never seen the information before.

I recommend this class ( although, I know it's not particularly enjoyable for a lot of people), for a few reasons. I had a bit programming background beforehand ( like I know what iteration and recursion are, but that's about it), and that makes me life slightly easier. 

1. It's a useful class. MatLab is a language used frequently in research ( the postdoc in my lab literally uses it everyday, but it also depends on the work you do ofc) 2. It's a nice intro to biological computations and biological simulation, because the models are basic and easy. It opens you to another way of thinking biological systems.   3. This class is nicely structured. Four units, 6 lectures per unit. Can't be clearer than that. The materials are nicely organized, and TAs and Prof Mak are helpful ( you gotta seek out for resources. Prof Mak might seem nonchalant (might be true) ,but he knows what he is talking about ( compare to some other class, in which the prof doesn't know his or her own stuff)). 

So take it if you are BME, get some programming background for yourself beforehand, and enjoy the class. If you are not BME and you just want to take a CS class that's somehow bio-related, don't take this class, cuz its modeling is not that eye-opening.

It's alright if you're looking to learn how to use MATLAB (or if you need it for the BME major).  And the material is learnable if you listen in class and look over the posted codes and do the psets - it's just SO boring, and the instructor is extremely unengaging and monotone.
